Text saved: A lifeboat is a small boat. It helps people when a big ship has a problem.

At first, Pi is very scared of the animals. So he jumps into the ocean. But he sees hungry sharks in the water. He knows he must go back to the lifeboat. It is his only choice.

On the boat, the animals kill each other. They also eat each other. Soon, only Pi and the tiger are left. Pi calls the tiger Richard Parker. Pi is lucky because the tiger is seasick. Seasick is when you feel sick on a boat. So the tiger does not want to eat him now.

- The primary failure is the loss of cause-and-effect. The original text connects Pi's actions to his feelings and realizations: he is terrified, so he jumps; he remembers the sharks, so he realizes he must climb back. Your version presents these as a list of separate facts ('Pi is very scared. So he jumps.'), which weakens the meaning of desperation.
- The original phrase 'realises his only option is to climb back' describes a moment of sudden understanding. Your version, 'He knows he must go back to the lifeboat. It is his only choice,' is a simple statement of fact and loses the critical meaning of realization.
- The original uses 'till only Pi and the tiger are left' to describe a process of elimination. Your use of 'Soon' changes this meaning to a simple statement about time.

Suggestion: Rephrase to restore the cause-and-effect relationships. Use simple connectors like 'so' and 'because' to link actions to reasons directly. For example: 'Pi is scared of the animals, so he jumps into the ocean. But he must go back because there are sharks in the water.' This structure preserves the original meaning more accurately.
